title: Latina Students Want “White Girls” to Stop Wearing Hoop Earrings
text:
Jorge Ramos Tells Latinos America Is “Our Country”… Liberals Don’t Bat an Eye 
One of the graffiti perpetrators was Alegria Martinez, a resident assistant at the college and a member of “Latinx Student Union.” She defended the message in an email sent to the entire student body, according to the Claremont Independent, a student-run news magazine . 
“(T)he art was created by myself and a few other WOC (women of color) after being tired and annoyed with the re-occurring theme of white women appropriating styles … that belong to the black and brown folks who created the culture,” she wrote. 
“The culture actually comes from a historical background of oppression and exclusion. The black and brown bodies who typically wear hooped earrings, (and other accessories like winged eyeliner, gold name plate necklaces, etc) are typically viewed as ghetto, and are not taken seriously by others in their daily lives. Because of this, I see our winged eyeliner, lined lips, and big hoop earrings serving as symbols (and) as an everyday act of resistance, especially here at the Claremont Colleges.” Advertisement - story continues below 
The college student then continued to state that her white fellow students wear the jewelry in an inappropriate, casual way. 
“Meanwhile we wonder, why should white girls be able to take part in this culture (wearing hoop earrings just being one case of it) and be seen as cute/aesthetic/ethnic. White people have actually exploited the culture and made it into fashion,” she concluded. 
Perhaps the most shocking part is the college supports this kind of divisiveness on their campus. According to the Pitzer website, the college even advertises its wall of “artistic representations of local and global issues that usually spark educational discussion across campus!” 
Describing the Pfizer controversy in a National Review Online column , writer and Fox News personality Katherine Timpf summed the inanity up succinctly. No one culture in America holds ownership over any element it produces — because one reason the country succeeds is that the best of all cultures are available for adaptation.
